heading: net, tech stocks take dive
subheading: is the party over? nah. share prices are just being tweaked after soaring to nosebleed-producing altitudes. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: no one's ready to say the bubble has popped for high-flying internet stocks. but if it hasn't, they were still getting a good butt-kicking thursday as investors succumbed to one of those periodic moments of clarity as to how much these suckers cost. tech shares also took a whipping after pacing the market's advance for weeks. while many top manufacturers are reporting solid earnings growth, traders remain wary of how these guys will fare in coming quarters.the dow jones industrial average shed 66.17 points to 9269.74 in mid-afternoon trading, and the wired index was 25.09 lower at 603.06. the nasdaq composite index fell 58.35 to 2357.14, and the s&p 500 was down 17.83 at 1238.79."it's three steps forward, two steps back," said ulric weil, an analyst with friedman, billings, ramsey. "the nasdaq has outperformed the dow and s&p for so long, some adjustment was due sooner or later."adjustment -- now there's a pleasant word for the slasher film showing in the internet section. yahoo (yhoo) slid 10 percent to us$257.88, excite (xcit) dropped 14 percent to $82.75, and ebay (ebay) was down 13 percent at $185.81. america online (aol), amazon.com (amzn), infoseek (seek) -- all lower.then there's lycos (lcos), now the star of a guessing game as to who will buy a piece (or more) of the portal, and when. lycos, soon-to-be parent of wired news, advanced $5.44 to $110.25 after confirming that it is indeed seeking an investor to purchase as much as 20 percent of the company.lycos is mum as to who it may be talking to in this regard, but the rumor mill places german media titan bertelsmann high on the list. other frequently mentioned prospects include microsoft, cbs, time warner and news corp.in tech, intel (intc) slipped $3.69 to $134.56 after saying it will invest $100 million in south korea's samsung electronics, the world's largest supplier of dynamic random access memory chips. the two companies will cooperate in developing a new generation of heavy-duty memory technology.international business machines (ibm) gained 69 cents to $195.19 as the market awaited word of big blue's fourth-quarter earnings after the closing bell. it's expected to come through with profit of at least $2.45 a share. dell computer (dell), meanwhile, shed $1.25 to $84.06, and microsoft (msft) was down $2.50 at $160.13.lucent technologies (lu) reported record quarterly profit of $1.05 a share, but its stock fell $8 to $107.50 as investors expressed their disappointment that the amount wasn't even higher. a pretty harsh judgment considering that lucent's net income was up no less than 26 percent from a year earlier.from the baby bells, sbc communications (sbc) lost $1.63 to $56.88 as it posted net income of 38 cents a diluted share, and ameritech (ait) was $1.31 lower at $67.69 as it unveiled profit of 68 cents a diluted share. both results were in line with expectations, but traders are still mulling the pending merger of the two telcos, trying to get a fix on how all the pieces will fit together.lastly, today's thoroughly unjustified net-related gain: the publishing company of north america (pcna), which prints membership directories for bar associations, climbed 288 percent to $3.88 after saying it will create an online portal for the legal community.boy, it's about time, huh?
